conclusion: Static Equilibrium Analysis of Three-Body System
Solve problem by analyzing forces on hemispherical bodies to find normal and frictional forces on body A

Understanding the setup: Three hemispherical bodies A, B, C with radii R, masses m, 2m, m; A and B on rough surface with friction coefficient μ = √3/6; C on A and B with smooth surface; bodies in static equilibrium
Body C rests in a saddle formed by A and B
Normal forces from A and B must be perpendicular to C's surface at points of contact due to symmetry and smooth surface
Normal forces N₁ and N₂ directed at angles of 30° from vertical due to geometry of three equal-radius circles in contact
Analyze forces on body A: Weight mg downward, normal force F from ground upward, frictional force f from ground (horizontal), normal force N₁ from body C
Resolve N₁ into components: Vertical component N₁cos(30°) = N₁(√3/2), Horizontal component N₁sin(30°) = N₁(1/2)
Vertical equilibrium for body A: F - mg + N₁(√3/2) = 0
Horizontal equilibrium for body A: f - N₁(1/2) = 0
Analyze forces on body B: Weight 2mg downward, normal force from ground upward, frictional force from ground (horizontal), normal force N₂ from body C
Total system analysis: Total horizontal component of friction must be zero, f + f_B = 0
Friction forces on A and B must be equal in magnitude and opposite in direction
Vertical components of N₁ and N₂ must support C's weight: N₁(√3/2) + N₂(√3/2) = mg
Horizontal components must cancel: N₁(1/2) = N₂(1/2)
Vertical equilibrium for body A: F = mg - N₁(√3/2) = mg/2
Horizontal equilibrium for body A: f = N₁(1/2) = mg/(2√3)
Verify friction is within limits of static friction: f ≤ μF = mg/(2√3)
